pgTitle: List of named passenger trains of the United Kingdom

rows.text:
{{stnlink|Aberdeen}} – {{Stnlink|London King's Cross}}
(sleeper service - later Night Aberdonian)
{{Stnlink|London Liverpool Street}} – Harwich Parkeston Quay – ferry – {{Stnlink|Hoek van Holland Haven}} – {{Stnlink|Amsterdam Centraal}}
{{Stnlink|London Liverpool Street}} – Harwich Parkeston Quay – Harwich Town{{sfnp|Allen|1947|p=67}}
{{Stnlink|London Liverpool Street}} – Harwich Parkeston Quay– ferry – {{Stnlink|Hoek van Holland Haven}} – {{Stnlink|Amsterdam Centraal}}
Birmingham Pullman{{efn-lr|name=BluPul|One of the '''''[[British Rail Classes 251 and 261|Blue Pullman]]''''' trains.}}
{{Stnlink|London Paddington}} – {{stnlink|Bristol Temple Meads}} non-stop (Original) {{Stnlink|London Paddington}} to {{Stnlink|Weston-super-Mare}} (current)

InterCity West Coast /
ScotRail (British Rail) / ScotRail (National Express) / First ScotRail / Caledonian Sleeper

London King's Cross – {{Stnlink|Aberdeen}}
(non-stop London King's Cross to Edinburgh Waverley)

Cheltenham Spa Express
(also known as The Cheltenham Flyer)
LNER / BR / Anglia / National Express East Anglia / Abellio Greater Anglia

{{Stnlink|London King's Cross}} – {{Stnlink|Edinburgh Waverley}} (non-stop){{efn-lr|Advertised as non-stop in summer 1962 but stopped for crew change at Newcastle after introduction of [[British Rail Class 55|Deltic]] traction.}}
{{Stnlink|Belfast Central}} ({{Stnlink|Belfast Great Victoria Street}} until 1976) & {{Stnlink|Dublin Connolly}}

Fife Coast Express
(Ran as Fifeshire Coast Express 1912 – 1939)
GNR+NER+NBR / LNER / BR / GNER / NXEC / East Coast / VTEC / LNER

{{Stnlink|London King's Cross}} – {{Stnlink|Edinburgh Waverley}}
From May 2011: Edinburgh to London, one way only
BR / GNER / NXEC / East Coast / VTEC

Kentish Belle (Pullman train)
formerly the Thanet Belle
London – to Margate, Broadstairs and Ramsgate
{{Stnlink|Liverpool Lime Street}} – London Euston and vice versa
{{Stnlink|Manchester Piccadilly}} – London Euston and vice versa

{{Stnlink|Sheffield Victoria}} – {{Stnlink|London Marylebone}}
after 1958 to {{Stnlink|London King's Cross}}, later to St Pancras
after privatisation from {{Stnlink|Leeds}} to {{Stnlink|London St Pancras}} via {{Stnlink|Sheffield}}.
From 2008 no longer from Leeds starting again at Sheffield.

1930s to transfer of all Scottish sleepers to Euston
Jan 2016 – Mar 2016

London King's Cross – Newcastle Tyne Commission Quay
(to connect with Bergen Line or Fred Olsen Line shipping services to Norway).
{{Stnlink|Manchester London Road}} (or {{Stnlink|Manchester Mayfield}}), Liverpool and {{Stnlink|Sheffield Midland}} – {{Stnlink|Bournemouth West}} and {{Stnlink|Poole}}

{{Stnlink|Glasgow Queen Street}} – {{Stnlink|London King's Cross}}
via {{Stnlink|Harrogate}} and {{Stnlink|Leeds Central}}

{{Stnlink|Glasgow Central}} – {{Stnlink|Carlisle}} –{{Stnlink|Leeds}} – {{Stnlink|London St Pancras}}
before 1966 from {{Stnlink|Glasgow St Enoch}}

{{Stnlink|Edinburgh Waverley}} – {{Stnlink|Carlisle}} –{{Stnlink|Leeds}} – {{Stnlink|London St Pancras}}
(Re-introduced in 1957 by BR as Waverley)

Thanet Belle (Pullman train)
later the Kentish Belle
London King's Cross – Newcastle Central (sleeper train)
{{Stnlink|London Victoria}} – Paris Est – Venice Santa Lucia
